At 06:03 27/03/2007, Steven Waits wrote:

>On Mar 26, 2007, at 7:56 PM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:
>
>>You guessed right. Evolving the spaceship was like a revelation for
>>me.
>
>Awesome.  That you could look at the spaceship, and come up with 
>this, says volumes.
>
>Now if only we silly humans could better visualize four 
>dimensions.  (I can think of a few messy ways - it'd be neat to fly 
>through the CPNN function space.)

You can teach yourself to visualise 4D if you work on it.  There's a 
few basic techniques:

1) think of a cube, think of it as red.  Think of another cube, think 
of it as green.  Put them at the same location.  These two cubes can, 
if you like form the end-stops of a 4D space, where the 4th 
coordinate is colour interpolated smoothly from red to green.  All we 
need to do is have a rule that things which are different colours are 
separated...

2) or, the net of a hypercube can be visualised as a small cube 
inside a large cube and with each corner of the inner cube connected 
to the matching corner of the outer cube.  Now tell yourself that the 
smaller cube isn't smaller, it's further away...  Each trapezoid 
(e.g. wormed by one face from each cube and the 4 joining lines) is 
really also a cube (but angled away from you)...

And so on.  I'm sure web-resources exist if you search for them.

Must go now, I'm due in the 17th century three feet ago.

         Ian
